moves.1. d4: Here's an very interesting game i playdd against a player called cedoran
moves.3. e4 f5: A weakening move that signals long castle
moves.4. Nc3 fxe4: Not a really good move, because it gives white a nice knight
moves.5. Nxe4 Qd5: Really odd move, bringng the queen out really early
moves.6. Nc3: Places the knight back on its natural square
moves.6... Qf7 7. Nf3 e6: Another pawn move. Black hasnt brought out any minor pieces
moves.9. Bb3 Bd7 10. O-O Bd6 11. Be3 Qh5 12. Q: I was a bit worried about black liberating his lsb with e5
moves.13... Nbc6 14. Rad1 e5 15. Ng5: Just threatening bf7ch winning the queen
moves.17... Qg6 18. Nxd8 Bxh3: Here i got a bit worried, but i found a forced sequence of moves which save the day
moves.19. Be6+ Bxe6 20. Nxe6 Qxe6 21. d5: D5! My opponent apparently missed this when playing bh2
moves.21... Qg6 22. dxc6 Nxc6: And white is in a winning position, but he has to be careful, black might have some tricks up his sleeve
moves.23. Nd5 Re8 24. Qd2 e4 25. g3: I wanted to blunt out the bishop and i thought i can handle a knight coming to f3
moves.25... Ne5 26. Qc3: I thought about nb6ch a long time, but decided to add more pressure on black
Defends against the mate threat with tempo
moves.29... Be5 30. Qc4: The pawn on b2 is immune
moves.32. Ne7+: Ne7ch!! No matter what black does he loses. 1.If 32... kb8?? 33. Rxd6! Winning a piece 2.if 32... kd7?? 33.nxg6! (Notice how blacks bishop is pinned) 3.32... rxe7??33.rxd6! Threatens mate and attacks the queen and fourth is the game continuation 32...bxe7?? 33.Qxe7! is mate no matter what black does
